title: VETERANS DISGRACE: MPs get bigger pay rise than army heroes in ‘BETRAYAL’
text:
VETERANS DISGRACE: MPs get bigger pay rise than army heroes in ‘BETRAYAL’ VETERANS DISGRACE: MPs get bigger pay rise than army heroes in ‘BETRAYAL’ THERESA May has been accused of an “utter betrayal” of war veterans after MPs received a bigger pay rise than Britain’s army heroes. PUBLISHED: 11:19, Mon, Feb 27, 2017 | UPDATED: 11:51, Mon, Feb 27, 2017 GETTY British heroes and widows will see their pension handouts rise one per cent 
About 140,000 British heroes and widows will see their pension handouts rise one per cent - by as little as £1.10 per week. 
Yet just four days earlier, the Prime Minister confirmed MPs will receive a 1.4 per cent pay rise this April. Related articles Chakrabarti PRAISES lawyer who chased after brave British troops 
The Government has been accused of failing its veterans and their families. 
The decision to up the benefits contributions by just one per cent was quietly released by the Ministry of Defence earlier this month. GETTY Theresa May has been accused of betraying veterans GETTY The Government has been accused of failing its veterans 
The War Pensions scheme was set up to aid those who suffer injury or illness caused by Armed Forces service before April 2005. 
It also helps to support the wives, husbands or civil partners of those killed while on duty. 
Christina Schmid, whose bomb-disposal expert husband was killed in Afghanistan in 2009, blasted the Prime Minister and her cabinet. 
She said: “There is clearly one rule for politicians and another for the rest.” 
SIGN OUR PETITION TO GET BETTER HOUSING AND MENTAL HEALTH CARE FOR VETERANS: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/182429 
And furious MPs and former serviceman and woman have blasted the decision. 
Tory backbencher Anne Marie Trevelyan warned the Government is breaking its promise to support heroes in their later life. 
She told the Sun: “It is disappointing that whilst the War Pension rate has increased, it has not done so at the same rate as the state pension. PA 1 of 68 Prince Harry attends a reception with veterans who took part in the D-Day landings in 1944 
“We must remember the Armed Forces Covenant states that those who have been injured as a result of their service to the country are entitled to receive increased levels of support, and we must ensure that level is fair and representative of the sacrifice our armed forces personnel have made.” 
UKIP defence spokesman Bill Etheridge MEP called the pension increases "shameful" and accused the government of "putting politicians before heroes." 
He also accused the Prime Minister of being "a hypocrite who talks patriotically but doesn't care about our servicemen and women." GETTY The MoD link the annual increase to inflation the previous year There is no excuse that will wash for this. It is an utterly betrayal. Lib Dem leader Tim Farron 
Cllr Etheridge added: "Come remembracetide politicians of all hues like to be seen with soldiers and veterans but the rest of the year they forgot about the military covenant. 
"We need an overhaul in the way we treat our veterans including priority for housing and healthcare as current legislation is a sham." 
Lib Dem leader Tim Farron demanded the Government guarantees a rise of a minimum of 2.5 per cent, adding: “The Prime Minister talks about a country that works for everyone, unless you served and then, it seems, the government don’t care. 
“There is no excuse that will wash for this. It is an utterly betrayal. These people served bravely and valiantly for our country, the least we can do is support them.” GETTY Express.co.uk launched a campaign to demand Homes for Heroes 
But the MoD link the annual increase to inflation the previous year - and note the payments come on top of the state pensions. 
A statement from the department said: “This pension is a compensation payment. 
“Like other public service schemes, it is updated in line with inflation.” 
The rise comes after Express.co.uk launched a campaign to demand Homes for Heroes after it was revealed 7,000 mentally traumatised war veterans are rotting on the streets of Britain. GETTY The War Pensions scheme was set up to aid those who suffer injury or illness 
The Armed Forces Covenant and Community Covenant were introduced in 2012 as a contract stating Britain’s war heroes should take priority when it comes to affordable housing – all 407 local authorities signed up to it. 
But they aren’t working - leaving thousands of ex-servicemen and women living rough and in desperate need of a roof over their head. 
Express.co.uk in conjunction with the charity Veterans Association UK is now demanding this loophole is closed and that when it comes to council homes priority MUST be given to those who have served their nation rather than those who have just arrived here. Related articles
